en.title: European Blue Card Visa (EU Blue Card)

hero.subtitle: Your Strategic Path to Work and Live in the Heart of Europe

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: The European Blue Card is one of the most important work and residence permits in Europe, specifically designed for highly qualified professionals from outside the European Union. This card grants you the opportunity to legally work and reside in an EU member state, with the possibility of moving to other countries later, making it a strategic choice for building a professional future and a stable life in the heart of Europe.

importance.title: The Importance of the Blue Card
points: Addressing the European Labor Market Shortage: The card targets experts in demanded fields such as IT, engineering, medicine, and science.
Freedom of Movement: After a certain period of residence, you can move to another European country without needing to start the procedures from scratch.
Family Stability: It allows for simplified and fast family reunification.
Permanent Residency Opportunity: In some countries like Germany, you can apply for permanent residency after only 21â€“27 months if you are proficient in the German language.

countries.title: Main Countries Offering the Blue Card

list.name: Germany
list.description: The most sought-after destination due to its strong economy and diverse job opportunities.

list.name: France
list.description: An environment rich with opportunities in research, engineering, and science.

list.name: Spain
list.description: An attractive option for professionals seeking a blend of professional life and vibrant culture.

countries.note: Almost all EU member states offer the Blue Card, with the exception of Denmark and Ireland.

requirements.title: Essential Requirements
list: A recognized university degree or equivalent professional qualification
A job contract or job offer from an employer in the European Union
A minimum annual salary threshold (varies by country, e.g., in Germany: â‚¬48,300 in 2025, or â‚¬43,759 for shortage occupations)
Health insurance covering the period of residence
Proof that the job is related to your academic or professional specialization

steps.title: Secure a Job Contract
steps.description: Obtain a job contract from a European company or institution

steps.title: Qualification Recognition
steps.description: Ensure your qualifications are recognized (e.g., via the ZAB office in Germany)

steps.title: Prepare Documents
steps.description: Gather passport, photos, job contract, academic qualification, proof of salary, and health insurance

steps.title: Submit Application
steps.description: Submit the application at the embassy, consulate, or immigration office in the target country

steps.title: Wait for Decision
steps.description: Processing may take from 8 weeks to several months, depending on the country

steps.title: Receive Blue Card
steps.description: Upon approval, receive the Blue Card and start working

documents.title: Required Documents

items: Valid passport (preferably covering the entire expected duration of stay)
Recent personal photos (compliant with European biometric standards: 35x45 mm, light background)
Recognized university degree or equivalent (must be officially recognized in the target country)
Qualification recognition certificate (e.g., via ZAB or ANABIN database in Germany)
Experience letters or previous employment contracts to prove professional experience
Signed employment contract or official job offer from an EU employer
Proof of annual salary (must exceed the minimum required in the country, e.g., â‚¬48,300 in Germany for 2025, or â‚¬43,759 for shortage occupations)
Proof of financial capacity (usually through the employment contract itself, but a bank statement may be requested)
Comprehensive health insurance covering the residence period from the first day
Completed and signed National Visa (D-Visa) application form
Updated CV according to European standards (Europass CV)
Motivation Letter explaining your choice of the country and job
Marriage or birth certificates (if applying with family)

notes: All non-English or non-German documents must be certified translation and legalized
Some European countries may request additional specific documents (such as a clear criminal record or a health certificate)
Originals and copies must be submitted together upon application
Documents vary slightly from one country to another, but Germany, France, and Spain have similar essential requirements

en.validity: 4 years or contract duration plus 3 months

fees.title: Fees and Costs
notes: Fees are non-refundable even if the application is rejected
Costs vary slightly from one European country to another, but Germany is considered the most common destination
The card is usually granted for 4 years or the contract duration plus 3 months, with the possibility of extension

benefits.title: Key Advantages
list: Legal residence and work in the EU
Possibility of moving to other European countries after a period of residence
Application for permanent residency after a specified period

with_kaya.title: What We Offer You at Kaya
services: Specialized consultations to determine your eligibility for the Blue Card
Preparation of your academic and professional file according to the requirements of each country
Step-by-step follow-up of the application until visa issuance
Additional support for your family in case of family reunification application
Guidance after arrival regarding registration and integration into the labor market

cta.title: Start Your European Journey Today
cta.description: With Kaya, the European Blue Card is not just a work permit; it is the beginning of a new life in the heart of Europe.
